elements.title: The Vatican Rag (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that some Catholics considered Tom Lehrer's "The Vatican Rag" (audio featured) to be blasphemous?

elements.title: Hilda Hilst (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Hilda Hilst impersonated a journalist to meet Marlon Brando, and asked him about Franz Kafka's works?

elements.title: Legislative Council of the Autonomous Kurdistan Region (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that after the Iraqi government lost control of its northern territories following the 1991 Gulf War, the Legislative Council of the Autonomous Kurdistan Region was based in Baghdad?

elements.title: not criminal (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the killing of hundreds of thousands of Soviet civilians by starvation in the siege of Leningrad was ruled not criminal by an American court?

elements.title: Stella Alexander (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Stella Alexander, the first female mayor of Issaquah, was nicknamed "Madame Mussolini" by her detractors?

elements.title: Brian Merrett (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Canadian photographer and architectural activist Brian Merrett's works prompted the preservation of Montreal's Shaughnessy House, now the Canadian Centre for Architecture?

elements.title: Susan Murabana (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Susan Murabana created Africa's first permanent planetarium?

elements.title: NYT_first_said (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that @NYT_first_said's most popular tweet, as of 2019, was simply "shithole"?
